com.yantra.api.omp.order

Interface splitLine

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    com.yantra.api.OMPApi, YIFApi

    public interface splitLine

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      org.w3c.dom.Document splitLine(YFSEnvironment env, org.w3c.dom.Document inXML)
      The splitLine API is used to split an OrderLine into two OrderLines.

    • Method Detail

      • splitLine

        org.w3c.dom.Document splitLine(YFSEnvironment env,
                               org.w3c.dom.Document inXML)
                        throws com.yantra.yfs.japi.YFSException,
                               java.rmi.RemoteException
        The splitLine API is used to split an OrderLine into two OrderLines. All or part of a line can be rejected and accepted with some other terms. Line splitting is allowed only for Product lines and not for Delivery or Provided Service Lines. When an OrderLine is split, the OrderLineKey of the original line is assigned to the OrigOrderLineKey attribute of the new OrderLine.

        Some examples of when to use the splitLine API are:

          Splitting an existing line to accomodate different ShipTo addresses
          Splitting a line based on schedules
          Splitting a line to perform item substitution

        The functionality of splitLine can be achieved by partially cancelling an existing OrderLine and adding a new line to the order. If the calling application cancels and adds information to a line, then the entire set of information for the new line must be provided in the input XML. By contrast, when using splitLine, the calling application needs to specify only the information that is different from the original line; the remaining line information is copied from the original line. A line in post released status should be split to a status that is less than released status.

        Entitlement Rules

        • Customer Entitlements: Customer entitlement rules get applied when ValidateItem flag is set to true on order line. The rules are applied based on Item Entitlement Strategy rule set by the customer's enterprise organization. The values of this rule are interpreted as follows:
          • 01 - Item entitlement logic is enforced based only on the item entitlement rules assigned to the customer.
          • 02 - Item entitlement logic is enforced based only on the pricelists assigned to the customer.
          • 03 - Item entitlement logic is enforced based on the intersection of item entitlement rules and pricelists assigned to the customer. This indicates that only the entitled items with valid price assigned will be presented to the customers.
          • 04 - Item entitlement logic is ignored.
        • Selling Entitlements: Selling entitlement rules get applied when the calling organization is not a catalog organization. These rules are applied regardless of what entitlement strategy is selected

        Related Documents
        Input XML Input DTD Output XML Output DTD Error XML Error DTD

        See Additional Information for details, include what occurs with chained and dependent lines.

        User Exits:
        com.yantra.ycm.japi.ue.YCMGetItemDetailsUE
        com.yantra.yfs.japi.ue.YFSRecalculateLineTaxUE

          This user exit is unconditionally called for the parent line but is called for a new line only if the element LineTax is not passed.

        com.yantra.yfs.japi.ue.YFSDetermineDateForPricingUE
        com.yantra.yfs.japi.ue.YFSGetTagNoUE
        com.yantra.yfs.japi.ue.YFSBeforeSplitLineUE

        Events Raised: These events are raised under transaction ORDER_CHANGE.
        ON_SUCCESS:
          This event is raised upon successful execution of splitLine.
          Data published - YFS_ORDER_CHANGE.ON_SUCCESS.xml
          Key data - modifyOrder_dbd.txt

        Template Support:
        Yes. Some of the elements and attributes are not template driven. Refer to input xml for element level details.
        ON_ORDER_RELEASE_STATUS_CHANGE:

          This event is raised when an order release status is changed for the order.
          Data published - YFS_ORDER_CHANGE.ON_ORDER_RELEASE_STATUS_CHANGE.xml
          Key data - modifyOrder_dbd.txt

          Template Support:
          Yes.

          Audits: Yes

          Pre-conditions: None

          Post Conditions: None

          Output Template Support:
          Yes. Some of the elements and attributes are not template driven. Refer to output xml for element level details.

          Database Extensibility Support: Yes

          Additional Information

          How splitLine works for n-tier order


            When splitLine is called for a line which has a quantity that is chained to another line, the split needs to be propagated to the chained line. This propagation occurs to both lines that this line is chained to, and to lines that this line is chained from.

            For example

              Line1 is chained to Line2 and Line2 is chained to Line3. splitLine is called, and Line2 is passed as the line to be split, and a quantity of 8 is to be split..

                Line1      --->  Line2      --->  Line3

              The following table gives the status for all of the lines in this example. Notice that some quantities on a line may be chained, and other quantities are not chained.

              Line Ordered
              Qty              		 Quantity
              by Status
              Status              		 ChainedTo
              Line
              Line1 20 5 --- ---
                  10 Chained Line2
                  5 Chained LineXYZ
              Line2 10 6 --- ---
                  4 Chained Line3
              Line3 4 4 --- ---

              Steps for splitting a line
              If any quantity that is chained to another line is removed because of the split, the same quantity is removed from the lines that it is chained to. The splitLine call indicates that a quantity of 8 should be removed from Line2.

              • Any quantity that is not chained to another line is removed first. The 6 units on Line2 which are not chained to another line are removed.
                A new line, Line2-A, is added, with its quantity set to 6.
              • This leaves 2 units on Line2 to be split.
                  The total of 8 units minus the 6 units just removed = 2 units remaining.

                The remaining 2 units are chained to Line3. The 2 units are removed from both Line2 and Line3.
              • Line2-A is assigned a quantity of 2. A new line, Line3-A, is created, and is also assigned a quantity of 2. The 2 units in Line2-A are chained to the 2 units in Line3-A, to preserve the chained relationship.
              • The quantity removed from Line2 must now be removed from Line1, to which it is chained. In this example, 8 units are removed from Line2 so they are also removed from Line1.
              • A new line Line1-A is added, with the OrderedQty set to 8. This new line, Line1-A, is chained to Line2-A.


              After the split, there are three new lines associated with the order: Line1-A, Line2-A, Line3-A.

              The results of the steps are:

              Line Ordered
              Qty              		 Quantity
              by Status
              Status              		 ChainedTo
              Line
              Line1 12 5 --- ---
                  2 Chained Line2
                  5 Chained LineXYZ
              Line2 2 0 --- ---
                  2 Chained Line3
              Line3 4 4 --- ---
              Line1-A 8 8 Chained Line2-A
              Line2-A 8 6 --- ---
              Line2-A   2 Chained Line3-A
              Line3-A 2   --- ---

              Schedules are never propagated in any direction. Only LotNumber is carried over to the new line from the parent line. The rest of the attributes are taken from the line that is getting added. LotNumber is not carried over when split takes place because of item substitution.

              Schedule information can not be passed for the new line. If a change to a schedule is required, use changeSchedule.

            How dependency is handled for splitLine


              Partial Split on Parent Line
              The new line does not have any dependency information unless the splitLine input xml provided dependency information. No dependency information is carried over from the parent.

              Complete Split on Parent Line
              The new line replaces the old parent line. All the children of the original parent line are now the children of the new parent line.

              Partial Split on Child Line
              The new line gets the same parent line as the existing child line has.

              Complete Split on Child Line
              The new line replaces the old line, and keeps the old line's relationships.

              • The new child line is chained to the orginal parent line. Say, Line B depends on Line A and Line B is split completely. Line B-A is added for the split of Line B. Line B-A is also dependent on Line A.
              • The new line that gets added is a parent of all the lines dependent on the line that got split.

              Splitting a derived line
              When a split takes place on a line that is derived from another line, it may be necessary to inform the parent line.

                Reducing derived quantity
                If the SendMessageToParent value is Y for a derived line's document type, a message is sent to the parent line for the quantity that is being split. The parent's listener for this message may move the lines to the BeforeDerived status.

                Making new line derived from the same parent line
                The SplitLine template should have a DerivedFromLineKey if the new line should be derived from the same parent line. The transaction for the parent order's ProcessType, which has a DerivedDocumentType which is the same as the child order's document type, is triggered. This IncludeInDerivedOrder transaction changes the status of the quantity of the parent line which is equal to the OrderedQty of the child line.
                If the parent line does not have sufficient quantity to derive from, an error is thrown.

          How to split logical kit lines

            Logical kit lines can be split by cancelling the old line and creating a new line with the new logical kit components. For example, OrderLine 1 has two components, Comp1 and Comp2. If you want to modify Comp2 to be Comp3, this can be accomplished by the following input: 
               <Order OrderNo="SplitOrder1" EnterpriseCode="DEFAULT">
   <OrderLines>
     <OrderLine PrimeLineNo="1" QuantityToSplit="20" SubLineNo="1">
       <SplitLines>
         <SplitLine PrimeLineNo="2" OrderedQty="20" SubLineNo="1" KitCode="LK" >
           <Item ItemID="SplitItem1"  KitCode="LK"/>
           <KitLines>
             <KitLine ItemID="Comp1" KitQty="5" ProductClass="" UnitOfMeasure="" />
             <KitLine ItemID="Comp3" KitQty="16" ProductClass="" UnitOfMeasure="" />
           </KitLines>
         </SplitLine>
       </SplitLines>
     </OrderLine>
   </OrderLines>
 </Order>
            When splitting a logical kit and passing a custom template, you should ensure the KitLines element is not included in the template.

        Parameters:
        env - Required. Environment handle returned by the createEnvironment API.
        inXML - Required. For more information, see the associated input xml files.

        Returns:
        An XML document containing the latest order details and the audit details made to the order. For details on the output, refer to the associated output files.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - Java's default remote exception handler.
        com.yantra.yfs.japi.YFSException - Exception containing error codes in the standard error files.
